questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours. The head is at +3 with caput present and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is dropping to 90 bpm. What is the best way to deliver the head? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

In this scenario, the patient is a primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) who is in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for 2 hours. The second stage of labor in a primigravida can be allowed up to 3 hours if the mother and fetus are stable. However, in this case, the fetal heart rate has dropped to 90 bpm, indicating fetal distress, and the head is at +3 station, meaning it is very low in the pelvis, almost at the pelvic floor.

 

  • Outlet forceps are specifically designed for situations where the fetal head is at +3 station or lower. The head is visible at the introitus without separating the labia, and delivery needs to be expedited due to fetal distress. In this case, the application of outlet forceps is preferred because it allows for a quicker delivery compared to other methods. This is critical when there is evidence of fetal distress, as time is of the essence to reduce the risk of hypoxia.
  • Mid cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is higher in the pelvis, typically at 0 to +1 station. This option is not suitable in this case because the head is much lower, at +3 station.
  • Low forceps are used when the head is at +2 station, slightly higher than in this scenario. They are not appropriate when the head is at +3 station.
  • Ventouse (vacuum extraction) can be used at various stations, but it is generally slower to apply compared to forceps. Additionally, the presence of caput (swelling of the fetal scalp) can make it difficult to achieve the necessary suction for effective vacuum delivery. Therefore, outlet forceps are preferred in this scenario to ensure a quicker and more effective delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid cavity forceps: Incorrect because they are used when the head is at a higher station, typically 0 to +1, and the head is not yet at the pelvic floor.

 

Option B. Low forceps: Incorrect because they are more suitable when the head is at +2 station, not when it is already at +3 station.

 

Option D. Ventouse (vacuum extraction): While it could technically be used, it is not the best choice here because of the fetal distress and the presence of caput, which may hinder the effective application of the vacuum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with the fetal head at +3 station, outlet forceps are the preferred method of assisted delivery due to their speed and effectiveness, particularly when caput is present.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman has an endometrial thickness of 14 mm with an adnexal mass. A previous report of endometrial biopsy shows complex endometrial hyperplasia with the presence of atypical cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metastasis endometrial carcinoma to ovary

 

  • According to the given clinical scenario, patient most likely has Endometrial Carcinoma with metastasis to ovaries.
  • Transvaginal scan (TVS) is done in women with post-menopausal bleeding. Normal Endometrial thickness in postmenopausal women is ≤ 4mm. Endometrial biopsy is indicated in women with post menstrual bleeding with endometrial thickness > 5mm.
  • The risk of progress to endometrial carcinoma in a patient with complex hyperplasia with atypia is 29%
  • The most likely diagnosis would thus be endometrial cancer and with an adnexal mass would be an ovarian metastases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycystic ovarian disease: Diagnosis is based on the presence of 2 out of the following 3 criteria 1) Oligo and/or anovulation 2) Hyperandrogenism 3) Polycystic Ovaries on ultrasound.

 

Option C. Struma Ovarii: It is a rare type of ovarian teratoma containing thyroid tissue. Another type of monodermal teratoma is the strumal carcinoid secreting serotonin

 

Option D. Immature ovarian teratoma: This is a rare usually malignant germ cell tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial thickness > 5 mm in postmenopausal women with bleeding should prompt an endometrial biopsy, especially if complex hyperplasia with atypia is suspected due to the high risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Dutta Textbook of Gynaecology page 329, 460, 294

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

 

Anterior colporrhaphy is performed for cystocele.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

choices.text: Epithelial cells covered by bacteria
Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods
Doderlein bacili in the macrophage

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes in with a grayish-white vaginal discharge. Upon conducting a gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are observed. What are clue cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells that are covered by bacteria, which gives them a distinctive appearance. In the context of bacterial vaginosis, these cells appear with a fuzzy or irregular border due to the presence of small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface. The presence of clue cells is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, a condition caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degranulated neutrophils: Degranulated neutrophils are not clue cells. Neutrophils are involved in the immune response, and their degranulation refers to the release of granules that contain enzymes and other substances. They do not have the fuzzy appearance characteristic of clue cells.

 

Option C. Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods: Gardenella vaginalis is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis, but clue cells are not specifically Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods. Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by various types of bacteria, not a specific bacterium or rod-shaped bacteria.

 

Option D. Doderlein bacilli in the macrophage: Doderlein bacilli (lactobacilli) are normally present in the vagina and help maintain a healthy environment. They are not found within macrophages, nor are they related to the appearance of clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by bacteria, and their presence is indicative of bacterial vaginosis.

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.

 

Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.

 

Staging of CA Cervix

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text: A 12 weeks pregnant lady visited the doctor. On ultrasound, it was found she has a low-lying placenta. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat ultrasound at 32 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

At 12 weeks gestation, the presence of a low-lying placenta is often not a cause for immediate concern because the placenta typically "migrates" upward as the pregnancy progresses. This migration is due to the expansion of the uterus, which effectively moves the placenta away from the cervix. Therefore, the recommended management is to repeat an ultrasound between 28 to 32 weeks to reassess the position of the placenta. By this time, the majority of placentas that were initially low-lying will have moved to a safer position, allowing for a more accurate determination of whether there will be any complications related to placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step for a pregnant woman found to have a low-lying placenta at 12 weeks is to repeat the ultrasound at around 32 weeks to reassess the placenta's position and determine appropriate management.

questions.text: A 33-week multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, proteinuria: 3+. The next step of management would be? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MgSO4 IV

 

In the scenario of imminent eclampsia, neuro-prophylaxis with Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4) is recommended. Imminent eclampsia is characterized by symptoms such as severe headaches, visual disturbances, epigastric pain, and hyperreflexia, indicating that the woman is at high risk of developing seizures (eclampsia). MgSO4 is effective in preventing seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia and imminent eclampsia, as supported by the Magpie Trial, which is the largest comparative study demonstrating its efficacy.

 

The Magpie Trial (MgSO4 for Prevention of Eclampsia) showed that MgSO4 prophylaxis in women with severe pre-eclampsia effectively prevented the development of eclampsia, making it the standard of care for neuro-prophylaxis in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is an antenatal steroid used to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. It is administered in doses of 6 mg every 12 hours for a total of four doses. However, it is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option B. Betamethasone: Betamethasone, like dexamethasone, is also an antenatal steroid given to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. The typical regimen is 12 mg administered 24 hours apart for two doses. It is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option D. LSCS: The mode of delivery, whether vaginal or Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS), will depend on the status of the cervical os and other obstetric indications. LSCS is not a prophylactic measure for preventing eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is recommended for neuro-prophylaxis in women with severe or imminent eclampsia to prevent seizures.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1840

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

 

Explanation:

 

Progesterone only pills (POPs), also known as mini pills, act through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but they do not kill sperms in the cervical canal.

 

Incorrect. Progesterone only pills do not have a spermicidal effect. They do not kill sperm; instead, they work by altering the cervical mucus and preventing ovulation.

 

The mechanisms of action include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thickening the cervical mucus: This makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an egg.

 

Option B. Preventing ovulation: Although not as consistently as combined oral contraceptives, POPs can inhibit ovulation in some women.

 

Option D. Inhibiting penetration of sperm: By thickening the cervical mucus and affecting the endometrial lining, POPs inhibit the sperm’s ability to penetrate and fertilize an egg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone only pills prevent pregnancy by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and preventing sperm penetration, but they do not kill sperm in the cervical canal.

 

Ref: Page no 323, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as:
    • No menstruation by age 13 in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No menstruation by age 15 in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • In this context:
    • Option A: An 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts would not be classified as having primary amenorrhea since she is not yet 13.
    • Option B: A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea because she is older than 13 and has no secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
    • Option C: A 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.
    • Option D: A 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts: The girl is too young to be classified as having primary amenorrhea.

 

Option C. 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Option D. 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 13 without secondary sexual characteristics or by age 15 with secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee opinion menstruation in girls and adolescents (2015), Speroff’s gynecologic endocrinology 7th edition pg401, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 450

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.

 

Other tests for ovulation:

 

  • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.

 

Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.

 

Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg435

choices.text: Take 2 pills the same day and continue
Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week

questions.text: A 23y woman who is using the combined oral contraceptive pill misses 2 pills in the 3rd week of the pack. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Take 2 pills the same day and continue

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, the missed pill guidelines are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and continue the packet: Simply continuing the packet without taking the missed pills would increase the risk of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week: This option is more applicable for missing three or more pills, where additional precautions and possibly emergency contraception might be necessary.

 

Option D. Start a new packet immediately: This approach is necessary only when three or more pills are missed in the third week, to avoid a pill-free interval and ensure continued contraceptive protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If one or two combined oral contraceptive pills are missed in the third week, the woman should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, then continue the pack as scheduled, taking two pills in one day if necessary. This minimizes the risk of pregnancy.

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.text: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction

 

Explanation:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months postpartum. It is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction, rather than diastolic dysfunction. The diagnostic criteria for PPCM include:

 

  • Cardiac failure developing in the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure.
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy.
  • Echocardiographic evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30%) along with a dilated left ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery: Correct. PPCM develops within five months of delivery.

 

Option C. Absence of identifiable cause: Correct. PPCM is diagnosed in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.

 

Option D. Dilated left ventricle: Correct. PPCM is associated with a dilated left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction and occurs within the last month of pregnancy or up to five months postpartum, in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482185/

questions.text: A couple with 2 children who are not able to conceive for over an year now present to the OPD. The male partner is diagnosed to be having hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism. Which of the following is not true? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low prolactin levels

 

Explanation:

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by a deficiency of gonadotropins (LH and FSH), which leads to low testosterone levels and impaired spermatogenesis. This condition often results in oligospermia or azoospermia, contributing to infertility. Additionally, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is frequently associated with hyperprolactinemia rather than low prolactin levels.

 

  • Low LH and FSH: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is marked by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) due to inadequate secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Low testosterone: The low levels of LH lead to reduced stimulation of Leydig cells in the testes, resulting in low testosterone levels.
  • Oligospermia: The low levels of FSH result in impaired spermatogenesis, often leading to oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • Low prolactin levels (Incorrect): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is associated with hyperprolactinemia, not low prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropins, further exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low LH and FSH: True. Gonadotropin deficiency is a hallmark of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option B. Low testosterone: True. The deficiency in LH leads to low testosterone production.

 

Option C. Oligospermia: True. The deficiency in FSH leads to impaired spermatogenesis, causing oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A male with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism will have high prolactin levels, low gonadotropins (LH and FSH), low testosterone, and often oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 199, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:

 

  • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has a midline lesion on the labia majora, which indicates that the lesion is close to or crossing the midline. In cases of midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline, bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is necessary along with radical vulvectomy. This approach ensures that all potential pathways of lymphatic spread are adequately addressed.

 

New (2021) FIGO staging for carcinoma of the vulva:

 

  • Tumors 2 cm or less in size with 1 mm or less invasion: Treated by wide local excision.
  • Tumors more than 2 cm with more than 1 mm depth of invasion: Treated by modified radical vulvectomy with groin lymph node dissection.
  • LN dissection through separate incision: Lymph node dissection should be inguino-femoral.
  • Bilateral lymph node dissection: Performed for midline lesions and those within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Unilateral dissection: If the lesion is unilateral and ipsilateral nodes are negative, bilateral dissection is not necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection: This would be appropriate for unilateral lesions with no evidence of contralateral spread, but not for midline lesions.

 

Option C. Simple vulvectomy: Simple vulvectomy is not sufficient for managing invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a lesion size of 2 cm x 3 cm and potential for deeper invasion.

 

Option D. Chemoradiation with resection: Chemoradiation followed by resection is typically reserved for advanced or inoperable cases, or where there is a need to downstage the tumor before surgery. This case can be managed surgically given the size and lack of palpable lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline in squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva, radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is the appropriate management.

 

Ref: FIGO staging of CA vulva, Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1436, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 484-485.

questions.text: What is the dose of Ulipristal used in emergency contraception? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The dose of Ulipristal in emergency contraception is 30 mg to be taken within 72 hrs (can be taken upto 120hrs).

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dose of Ulipristal for emergency contraception is 30 mg, to be taken within 72 hours (up to 120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Pap smear
Visual inspection with iodine

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

  • Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.
  • Both diabetes and hypertension are risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma hence endometrial sampling would be the more appropriate test as compared to tests for cervical cancer screening.
  • Endometrial sampling is indicated in a woman with post-menopausal bleeding with the endometrial thickness is > 4 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A pap smear should be done in all women complaining of post menopausal women with a normal looking cervix and a cervical biopsy for all women with a cervical growth but in this question, based on risk factors, we are more worried about endometrial cancer and hence endometrial sampling is a better option.

 

Option B. Visual inspection with iodine: This is not the preferred option and even if cervical cancer screening is warranted, a pap smear or HPV is better.

 

Option C. Colposcopy: This is indicated if there is any cytological abnormality on the pap smear

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no 560, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the OPD. She has Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characters. Her karyotype is 46XX. FSH is 5 and LH is 13. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

 

The patient presents with primary amenorrhea, Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characteristics, a 46XX karyotype, and normal gonadotropin levels (FSH and LH). The development of secondary sexual characteristics indicates that the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis is functioning properly, which usually suggests normal ovarian function. Mullerian agenesis (also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a condition where the uterus and part of the vaginal canal are absent, but ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics remain normal. This condition commonly presents with primary amenorrhea in individuals with a 46XX karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis refers to underdeveloped or non-functional gonads, leading to low estrogen levels and subsequent lack of secondary sexual characteristics. In this case, FSH and LH levels would typically be elevated, not normal.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a lack of secondary sexual development due to low levels of gonadotropins (FSH and LH). This condition usually presents with delayed or absent puberty, unlike the normal Tanner stage IV development seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS): AIS involves individuals with a 46XY karyotype who are phenotypically female due to the body's inability to respond to androgens. This patient has a 46XX karyotype, ruling out AIS as a possible diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis is a likely diagnosis in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual development, normal FSH/LH levels, and a 46XX karyotype.

questions.text: A 25 yr G2P1 presents with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks. On examination, there is hypotension. The abdomen is tender and fetal parts not palpable. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a 25-year-old G2P1 woman presenting with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks of gestation, several key clinical features point towards a diagnosis of abruptio placenta.

 

Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is a condition where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall prematurely, leading to significant bleeding.

 

The critical signs here are:

 

  • Hypotension: This indicates significant blood loss, which can be seen in both placenta previa and placental abruption.
  • Tender abdomen: The tenderness of the abdomen is a hallmark of placental abruption due to the irritation and inflammation caused by the bleeding and the detached placenta.
  • Fetal parts not palpable: This is due to the tense and tender uterus, which is characteristic of placental abruption.

 

Abruptio placenta - Immediate management (delivery) is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

In contrast, placenta previa typically presents with painless bleeding, and the uterus is usually relaxed and non-tender. Placenta previa involves the placenta covering the cervical os, which can lead to painless bleeding without the tenderness seen in placental abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Usually presents with painless bleeding and a relaxed, non-tender uterus.

 

Option C. Show: Refers to the passage of a small amount of blood or mucus plug as labor begins, which does not cause significant bleeding or abdominal tenderness.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: While it can cause significant bleeding and abdominal tenderness, it is less common and typically associated with a history of uterine surgery or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding in Pregnancy after 28 weeks à is due to APH

 

2 MC causes are of APH are – Placenta Previa (Painless bleeding, nontender uterus) and Abruptio placenta (Painful bleeding, tense & tender uterus)

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea and a history of frequent abortions. FSH is 7. hCG is < 5. What is the cause of amenorrhea? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine disorder

 

The patient has normal FSH and hCG levels, indicating that the hypothalamus, pituitary, and ovarian functions are intact.

 

Note - FSH levels less than 10 are considered normal, and an hCG level of less than 5 indicates that the patient is not pregnant.

 

Given these normal hormonal profiles, the issue is likely not with the endocrine function but with the uterus itself. One possible uterine disorder that can cause amenorrhea is Asherman syndrome, which involves intrauterine adhesions (synechiae). This condition can follow frequent uterine procedures such as dilation and curettage (D&C) or infections, leading to a history of frequent abortions and subsequent amenorrhea due to scarring within the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary disorder: This would typically result in abnormal levels of FSH and LH due to issues with the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

 

Option B. Ovarian disorder: If the ovaries were not functioning properly, FSH levels would likely be elevated as the body tries to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Option D. Adrenal disorder: These disorders do not typically present with the specific combination of symptoms and normal hormonal profile seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal hormonal profile with amenorrhea and a history of frequent abortions suggests a uterine disorder, such as Asherman syndrome, where intrauterine adhesions disrupt the normal menstrual cycle.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Definition: Nuchal translucency refers to the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • Significance: An increased NT measurement is associated with an increased risk for fetal aneuploidy (such as Down syndrome) and various structural anomalies including cardiovascular defects, hydrops fetalis, and cystic hygroma.

 

Timing:

 

  • NT is measured between 11 weeks and 13 weeks 6 days (or 11-14 weeks) of gestation. This time frame is critical as it ensures the accuracy of the measurement and its correlation with potential anomalies.

 

Measurement Criteria:

 

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Should be between 45-84 mm.
  • Fetal Position: Fetus should be in the mid-sagittal plane and in a neutral position.
  • Image Quality: The image must be magnified, and the widest space should be measured.
  • Caliper Placement: The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space, ensuring the amnion is seen separately.

 

Screening Efficiency:

 

  • NT Alone: Provides a 65% detection rate for Down syndrome.
  • Combined Test: When combined with the Dual Marker test (beta hCG and PAPP-A), the detection rate for Down syndrome improves to 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6-8 weeks: This is too early for accurate NT measurement.

 

Option C. 14-16 weeks: This is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation, reducing the effectiveness of the screening.

 

Option D. 16-20 weeks: This period is too late for NT measurement, which should be performed in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation is between 11-14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A nulliparous woman presented with 26 weeks of gestation for routine antenatal check-up. Her blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. What can be the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine dipstick

 

  • A pregnant woman with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation should be evaluated for gestational hypertension or Pre-eclampsia.
  • So, the next step should be looking out for proteinuria by Urine dipstick test.  (Here Proteinuria refers to urine dipstick greater than or equal to +2 (1 gm/L) on at least two random clean catch samples   or a  total 24 hour urine protein > 0.3 gm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Uric Acid: Blood changes in pre-eclampsia may not be very specific however a serum Uric acid of more than 4.5 mg/dl may be considered as a biochemical marker

 

Option B. Liver Function tests and Option C. Complete blood count: LFTs may be raised and there may altered coagulation profile and thrombocytopenia

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation, the next best step is to evaluate for proteinuria using a urine dipstick test to screen for pre-eclampsia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics page 256, 262

questions.text: The ideal number of ANC visits is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12-15

 

Antenatal care (ANC) visits are crucial for monitoring the health of both the mother and the fetus during pregnancy. Different guidelines recommend varying numbers of visits:

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts."
  • American guidelines and practical recommendations: Advise 12-15 visits, ensuring comprehensive care.

 

The ideal number of ANC visits, according to American guidelines and actual practice, is 12-15. This schedule is designed to closely monitor the pregnancy and promptly address any complications:

 

  • Monthly visits until 28 weeks of gestation.
  • Bi-weekly visits from 28 to 36 weeks.
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks until delivery.

 

This frequency allows for timely detection and management of potential issues, ensuring the best outcomes for both mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of ANC visits is 12-15, as recommended by American guidelines, to ensure comprehensive prenatal care.

questions.text:
A couple already has 3 children and has been trying for another one for the last 1 year. However, the husband is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following is/are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Low FSH, low LH
  2. High FSH, low LH
  3. Oligospermia
  4. Low prolactin
  5. Low testosterone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 5

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where there is decreased production of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland, leading to decreased stimulation of the testes and consequent reduced production of sex hormones such as testosterone. This results in:

 

1. Low FSH, low LH: In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) are low due to inadequate stimulation from the pituitary gland.

 

3. Oligospermia: Reduced levels of FSH and LH lead to decreased stimulation of the testes, which can result in reduced sperm production and oligospermia (low sperm count).

 

5. Low testosterone: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leads to reduced levels of testosterone because the testes are not adequately stimulated by FSH and LH.

 

The following are not true for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism:

 

2. High FSH, low LH: This pattern is more characteristic of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (primary testicular failure) rather than hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

4. Low prolactin: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is typically associated with normal or high levels of prolactin if there is an underlying pituitary issue. Low prolactin is not a characteristic feature of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both FSH and LH levels are low, testosterone levels are low, and oligospermia is often present.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Abruptio placentae, also known as placental abruption, commonly occurs in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. It is characterized by the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and often fetal distress or fetal death. The uterus may be tonically contracted in such cases.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypertensive Disorders: Abruptio placentae is frequently associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  • Clinical Presentation: Painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements are hallmark signs.
  • Uterine Contraction: The uterus may feel firm and tender, indicating a tonic contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa involves painless vaginal bleeding due to the placenta covering the cervix. It generally does not cause decreased fetal movements unless there is severe bleeding leading to maternal and fetal compromise.

 

Option C. Hydramnios: Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) involves excessive amniotic fluid and does not typically present with bleeding.

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor typically does not present with bleeding and is characterized by regular uterine contractions leading to cervical changes before 37 weeks of gestation. Prematurity in preterm labor is iatrogenic if induced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abruptio placenta should be suspected in a hypertensive pregnant woman presenting with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements, as it is commonly associated with hypertensive disorders and presents with these clinical features.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1944

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent post-partum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gentle massage of uterus

 

AMTSL

 

Purpose: To prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), a major cause of maternal death.

 

  1. Give a uterotonic drug
    • Oxytocin 10 IU IM immediately after the birth of the baby
    • This helps the uterus contract and reduce bleeding
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
    • Gently pull the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus to help deliver the placenta
    • Only if trained and placenta is ready to come
  3. Intermittent uterine tone assessment

 

Delayed cord clamping

 

  • Wait 1–3 minutes before clamping the umbilical cord
  • Improves baby’s iron stores and reduces anemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonic within 1 minute of delivery: This is a critical step in AMTSL to prevent PPH by promoting uterine contractions.

 

Option B. Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord: Delayed cord clamping (after 1 to 3 minutes) is recommended for all births to enhance neonatal outcomes

 

Option D. Controlled cord traction: This is a part of AMTSL to aid in the delivery of the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active management of the third stage of labor includes the administration of a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and assessing uterine tone rather than sustained uterine massage for all women who have received a uterotonic.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/120082/WHO_RHR_14.20_eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: HPV Nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6, 11, 16, 18

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent HPV vaccine effective against 9 serotypes of the virus
  • These include: 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.merckvaccines.com/gardasil9/

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. This approach allows for the direct sampling of the lesion to assess for malignancy or other pathological changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conisation: Conisation is an excisional procedure that is typically performed once biopsy-proven cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step for a visible mass with postcoital bleeding.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure used for treating CIN1 or 2. It is not suitable for initial diagnosis or for lesions suspected of being malignant.

 

Option D. Pap smear: A Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. It is a screening tool and not diagnostic for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a symptomatic patient with a visible cervical lesion and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is the appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics.
Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given
Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of acute onset fever, and pain in the right lumbar region. It is associated with chills, nausea, and vomiting. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E. coli and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

 

Explanation:

 

The management of acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy involves several key steps to ensure effective treatment and prevent complications:

 

  • Hospitalization: Necessary for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring.
  • Urine and Blood Cultures: Essential for identifying the pathogen and tailoring antibiotic therapy.
  • Intravenous Crystalloids: Used to maintain adequate urine output (≥50 mL/h) and ensure proper hydration.
  • Antibiotics: Initially given intravenously, with the switch to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. The correct management protocol dictates:

 

  • Discharge Criteria: The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours, not 72 hours.
  • Duration of Antibiotics: The recommended course of antibiotics is 7 to 10 days, not just 5 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics: Correct. Hospitalization, urine and blood cultures, and starting antibiotics are all appropriate steps in managing acute pyelonephritis.

 

Option B. Oral antibiotics once afebrile: Correct. Switching to oral antibiotics is appropriate once the patient is afebrile.

 

Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given: Correct. Maintaining a urine output of > 50 mL/h and using intravenous crystalloids are standard practices to manage hydration and ensure adequate renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discharge from the hospital should be considered once the patient is afebrile for 24 hours, and antibiotics should be continued for 7 to 10 days in cases of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing, sneezing, or physical exertion. It is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse, where the support structures of the pelvic floor are weakened, leading to bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overflow incontinence: Overflow incontinence occurs when the bladder cannot empty properly, leading to frequent or constant dribbling of urine. It is usually secondary to an obstruction, such as an enlarged prostate in men or severe prolapse in women causing a kink in the urethra. This condition does not typically present with leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option B. Urge incontinence: Urge incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine accompanied by or immediately preceded by a sudden, intense urge to urinate. This type of incontinence can be due to overactive bladder syndrome, where there is involuntary contraction of the bladder muscles.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder refers to a dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to a central or peripheral nervous system pathology. This can result in various types of incontinence, including both overflow and urge incontinence, depending on the nature of the neurological impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heart disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery. In fact, NVD is preferred in heart disease patients. The second stage of labour is cut short with the use of instrumental vaginal delivery like forceps or ventouse assisted vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic tumor: Pelvic tumor if diagnosed may interfere with normal labor and needs to be evaluated before deciding the mode of delivery

 

Option B. Herpes infection:  Active herpes is an absolute contra-indication to a normal delivery due to the high viral shedding in the lesions and increased risk of neonatal herpes.

 

Option D. History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies: History of 2 or more previous cesareans is also a contra-indication to a vaginal delivery and hence induction is not done

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery, and NVD is preferred in heart disease patients.

 

Ref: Page no 332, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature cystic teratoma

 

The specimen shows an ovarian mass with a tuft of hair in a cystic space, which is characteristic of a mature cystic teratoma. Key points about mature cystic teratomas include:

 

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors: They contain various types of tissues derived from the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts): Typically unilocular and contain sebaceous material, hair, and sometimes other tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and neural tissues.
  • Presentation: Most patients are asymptomatic, but they may present with an abdominal mass, acute pain due to torsion of the ovary, or rarely due to rupture of the cyst.
  • Treatment: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy is the treatment of choice for mature teratomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immature teratoma: These are malignant and contain immature embryonic tissues, often neuroectodermal. They usually occur in younger patients and are more aggressive.

 

Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains mucinous material and does not contain hair or other tissues.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains clear serous fluid and lacks the complex tissues found in teratomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are characterized by the presence of multiple tissue types such as hair, sebaceous material, and sometimes teeth or bone within a cystic ovarian mass.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple screening test includes Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein (AFP), and Inhibin A. Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple test.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: At the 5th postnatal day, a woman presents with sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Postpartum blues

 

Explanation:

 

Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," typically occur within the first few days after delivery and can last up to two weeks. It is characterized by mood swings, sadness, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping. These symptoms are usually mild and self-limiting, resolving on their own with support and reassurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum depression: This condition occurs after the first two weeks post-delivery and can persist for months. It includes more severe symptoms such as persistent sadness, lack of interest in the baby, feelings of hopelessness, and possibly suicidal thoughts.

 

Option C. Postpartum anxiety: This condition involves excessive worry, anxiety, and often includes physical symptoms like palpitations or hyperventilation. It can occur at any time during the postpartum period.

 

Option D. Postpartum psychosis: This is a rare but severe condition that usually occurs within the first few weeks after delivery. It involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, severe agitation, and risk of harm to the mother or baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum blues are common in the first few days after delivery and are characterized by sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. The condition is generally mild and self-limiting, resolving with support and care.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with eclampsia is on a maintenance dose of MgSO₄. When will you stop MgSO₄? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine output 60ml in 4hr


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is used in eclampsia management to prevent seizures. However, MgSO₄ toxicity can occur, which necessitates stopping or adjusting the dose. The first sign of MgSO₄ toxicity is the absence of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), followed by respiratory depression and reduced urine output. Since magnesium is excreted through the kidneys, urine output is a critical measure of magnesium toxicity risk. A urine output of less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours) indicates poor excretion and potential toxicity, requiring immediate adjustment or cessation of MgSO₄.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee jerk present: The presence of a knee jerk (deep tendon reflex) is a positive sign and indicates that magnesium levels are not yet toxic. The absence of DTRs is the first indication of toxicity, so this is not a reason to stop MgSO₄.

 

Option B. RR 18/min: A respiratory rate above 10 breaths per minute is safe when on MgSO₄. Respiratory depression is a sign of advanced toxicity; therefore, a rate of 18 per minute is not concerning.

 

Option C. Visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are symptoms associated with eclampsia or pre-eclampsia (e.g., retinal detachment or blurred vision) but are not signs of MgSO₄ toxicity. These do not indicate the need to stop MgSO₄.

 

Educational Objective:


MgSO₄ should be stopped if the patient’s urine output is less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours), as this indicates poor excretion and risk of magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of the device shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trophoblastic disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a copper-containing IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device).
  • ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device are:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis/ Puerperal sepsis/ Current Pelvic inflammatory/ disease, Genital Tuberculosis
    • Cancers: Endometrial cancer, Cervical cancer, Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity, Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Menstruation: Intra-uterine device can be inserted even during periods although preferably it should be inserted post-menstrual

 

Option C. Immediately after delivery: This is called as Post placental IUCD insertion (within 10 mins of placental delivery)

 

Option D. Ruptured condom during intercourse: Following a ruptured condom, CUT can be inserted as an emergency contraception

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophoblastic disease is an ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549158

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for urinary incontinence following a hysterectomy. In the 3-swab test, the middle swab is stained with dye. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vesico-vaginal fistula

 

Explanation:

 

The 3-swab test is used to diagnose the presence and location of a fistula between the urinary tract and the genital tract following a hysterectomy.

 

 

3-swab Test:

 

  1. Three dry swabs are placed in the vagina:
    • Swab 1: Upper vagina
    • Swab 2: Middle vagina
    • Swab 3: Lower vagina
  2. Methylene blue dye is then injected into the bladder through a urinary catheter.
  3. After waiting for 5-10 minutes, the swabs are removed and examined for staining and wetness:
    • If the upper swab is wet but not stained with dye, it suggests a uretero-vaginal fistula since urine from the ureter is leaking into the vagina without dye.
    • If the middle swab is wet and stained with blue dye, it indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula because the dye from the bladder is leaking directly into the vagina through the fistula.
    • If the lower swab is stained and wet, it indicates a urethro-vaginal fistula.

 

In this case, the middle swab being stained with dye indicates that the fistula is between the bladder (vesica) and the vagina, confirming a vesico-vaginal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uretero-vaginal fistula: The upper swab would be wet but not stained with dye.

 

Option C. Utero-vaginal fistula: This is not relevant post-hysterectomy as the uterus has been removed.

 

Option D. Urethro-vaginal fistula: The lower swab would be stained and wet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive 3-swab test with the middle swab stained with dye indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula, which is a common complication following a hysterectomy where the bladder and vagina are abnormally connected.

 

Note – the best IOC in this case is – CT Urography

questions.text: What does this Cardio-Tocography show?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deceleration

 

Explanation:

 

The Cardio-Tocography (CTG) in question shows decelerations, which are characterized by a drop in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by at least 15 beats per minute (bpm) lasting for at least 15 seconds.

 

Types of Decelerations on CTG:

 

  1. Early Deceleration:
    • The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the uterine contraction.
    • Caused by head compression during contractions.
    • Commonly observed in the second stage of labor.
  2. Late Deceleration:
    • The nadir of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
    • Indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency, which can lead to fetal distress or hypoxia.
    • Considered an ominous sign and requires prompt evaluation and intervention.
  3. Variable Deceleration:
    • There is no fixed relationship between the deceleration and uterine contractions.
    • Caused by umbilical cord compression, often seen with oligohydramnios.
    • Significant if persistent, with FHR <70 bpm for more than 60 seconds.
  4. Prolonged Deceleration:
    • Occurs when the deceleration lasts beyond 2 minutes but less than 10 minutes.
    • May indicate acute fetal hypoxia, such as with cord prolapse or intrapartum abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acceleration: This would show an increase in the fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Normal: A normal CTG would not show any decelerations or would show a typical pattern of fetal heart rate variability and accelerations.

 

Option D. Deceleration followed by acceleration: This pattern would indicate a combination of deceleration and acceleration, which is not specified here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decelerations on a Cardio-Tocography indicate a decrease in fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, with different types signifying various conditions and levels of concern.

 

Ref: Page no 994, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Functional residual capacity
Inspiratory capacity

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration. During pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated due to the enlarging uterus, leading to a decrease in FRC by approximately 22%. This is primarily due to reductions in expiratory reserve volume and residual volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate: The respiratory rate typically remains unchanged during pregnancy, staying at about 14-16 breaths per minute.

 

Option B. Vital capacity: Vital capacity, which is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume, remains unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity increases during pregnancy by about 10%. This increase is due to the higher tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity decreases during pregnancy due to the elevation of the diaphragm caused by the enlarging uterus.

 

  • Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Page no 189, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Loss of knee jerk
Reduced muscle tone

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulfate. What is the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of knee jerk

 

  • Therapeutic range: The therapeutic range of magnesium for the prevention of seizures in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.
  • Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of DTRs, specifically the knee jerk reflex. This occurs when plasma magnesium levels reach 7-10 mEq/L.
  • Respiratory depression: When plasma magnesium levels reach 10-12 mEq/L, respiratory depression occurs. Beyond 12 mEq/L, respiratory paralysis and respiratory arrest can occur.
  • Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest can happen if serum magnesium levels exceed 25 mEq/L.
  • Monitoring: A patient on magnesium sulfate is monitored for toxicity by checking clinical signs, including DTRs, urine output, and respiratory rate.
  • Treatment of toxicity: Treatment for magnesium sulfate toxicity involves administering calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (1g intravenously) and discontinuing magnesium sulfate, which usually reverses mild to moderate respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Hypotension is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression occurs at higher magnesium levels (10-12 mEq/L), after the loss of knee jerk reflex.

 

Option D. Reduced muscle tone: Reduced muscle tone is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity and is less specific than the loss of DTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition page 759

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the most appropriate management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ART immediately and continue life long

 

Explanation:

 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) recommends that all pregnant women with HIV should start antiretroviral therapy (ART) immediately, regardless of the stage of their disease or their CD4 count. This approach is aimed at reducing the viral load as quickly as possible, thereby decreasing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. ART should be continued lifelong to ensure ongoing viral suppression and the health of the mother.

 

Management of HIV-positive pregnancy includes:

 

  1. Antenatal care:
    • Testing for other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), CMV, toxoplasmosis, tuberculosis, fungal, and other opportunistic infections.
    • Partner/husband should also be tested.
    • To prevent pneumocystis pneumonia, start co-trimoxazole if CD4 count is ≤ 250 cells/mm³ and continue through pregnancy, delivery, and breastfeeding (dose: double strength tablet, 1 tablet daily).
    • Assess immunization status and update as needed.
    • Counseling on the impact of HIV on pregnancy and factors influencing the progression of the disease and risk of perinatal transmission.
    • CD4 count testing in each trimester.
    • Monitor HIV RNA levels monthly after changing/initiating therapy.
    • CBC, LFT, and KFT in each trimester.
  2. Anti-retroviral therapy for all:
    • As per NACO: Start ART at diagnosis (regardless of CD4 count); continue lifelong.
    • Initiate lifelong ART in all pregnant women with confirmed HIV infection regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 cell count.
    • TDF + 3TC + EFV is recommended as first-line ART in pregnant and breastfeeding women (including pregnant women in the first trimester of pregnancy).
    • Pregnant women detected to be HIV-positive for the first time in labor should be initiated on ART (TDF + 3TC + EFV) immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Start ART immediately upon diagnosis of HIV in pregnancy and continue lifelong to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission and maintain the health of the mother.

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried female has come to the gynae OPD for cervical cancer vaccination. Which is preferred? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gardasil

 

Explanation:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for cervical cancer prevention. It is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that provides protection against four serotypes of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV): 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

  • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil:
    • 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts.
    • 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.

 

Gardasil is administered as an intramuscular injection with a recommended schedule of three doses (0, 2, and 6 months).

 

Available HPV Vaccines:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 16 and 18.
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  3. Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent, covers serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biovac: This is a vaccine for Hepatitis A, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option C. Rabivac: This is a rabies vaccine for animals, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tvac: This is a tetanus vaccine, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for preventing cervical cancer and related HPV diseases, covering serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/teams/immunization-vaccines-and-biologicals/diseases/human-papillomavirus-vaccines-(HPV)

choices.text: Mandatory episiotomy
Manual perineal support and warm compresses
Maintain head in deflexion and deliver
Deliver in lithotomy position only

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses


The WHO guidelines for managing the second stage of labor emphasize techniques to reduce perineal trauma and enhance maternal comfort. The use of manual perineal support and warm compresses is recommended to protect the perineum during delivery and reduce the incidence of severe perineal tears.

 

  • Manual Perineal Support and Warm Compresses:
    • Manual Support: Hands-on guarding of the perineum during delivery helps control the speed of delivery and reduces the risk of severe perineal tears.
    • Warm Compresses: Applying warm compresses to the perineum can help relax the tissues and make them more pliable, further reducing the risk of tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandatory Episiotomy: Not Recommended: Routine episiotomy is no longer recommended by the WHO. It is only indicated in specific cases where it is necessary to expedite delivery for the safety of the mother or baby.

 

Option C. Maintain Head in Deflexion and Deliver: Not Recommended: The recommendation is to allow the fetal head to assume the most optimal position for delivery rather than intentionally maintaining deflexion, which may hinder the delivery process.

 

Option D. Deliver in Lithotomy Position Only: Not Recommended: The WHO supports a variety of birthing positions based on the mother’s preference and comfort. Restricting delivery to the lithotomy position is not recommended; instead, women should be encouraged to choose their preferred position.

 

Educational Objective:


Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower -CG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
