  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct as PAPP-A is not part of the quadruple test and it typically decreases in Down syndrome.

 

Option C. Lower B-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), the quadruple test shows elevated β hCG and Inhibin A, and decreased AFP and uE3.

 

Ref: Page no 863, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
  • When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels (pituitary apoplexy) and panhypopituitarism. It is characterized by:
    • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
    • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
    • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
    • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion
    • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor Syndrome: Also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin

 

Option C. Prolactinoma: This will not present lactation failure. Instead, there will be galactorrhea and symptoms like headache, luring of vision due to pressure effects of the prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: It is a disorder that results in excess growth of certain parts of the human body. It is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed. The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet. There may also be an enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose. Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision. Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

 

Explanation:

 

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma.
  • Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair.
  • The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside.
  • Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing.
  • Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications.
  • Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months: This duration of abstinence is too short for the proper healing of the surgical site. Additionally, avoiding pregnancy for only 6 months might not provide sufficient time for the repair to gain adequate strength.

 

Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year: While the recommendation to avoid pregnancy for a year is appropriate, 6 weeks of sexual abstinence may still be insufficient for optimal healing of the fistula repair.

 

Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years: This recommendation is excessively long. While prolonged abstinence can prevent complications, a 6-month period is more than what is typically necessary. Similarly, avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is overly cautious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should be advised to abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year to ensure proper healing and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs
Two doses 12 hrs apart
Three doses 12 hrs apart
None of the above

questions.text: For emergency contraception, a single tab of 0.75 mg of LNG was taken, it should be followed by which of the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs

 

Explanation:

 

  • In this case, the 2nd dose of LNG 0.75 mg (levonorgestrel) is taken after 12 hours.
  • One tablet of LNG 0.75mg should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and another 12 hours later.
  • Alternately, two tablets (of 0.75mg) or a single 1.5mg tablet can be taken as a single dose.
  • The tablets can be offered up to 72h of an act of unprotected intercourse, but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

 

Other emergency contraceptives available:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency contraception using levonorgestrel requires a follow-up dose of 0.75 mg taken 12 hours after the initial dose to ensure efficacy.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent
MgSO4 is continued upto 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure
It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO4 is false? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

 

The statement that MgSO4 has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP is false. MgSO4 is indeed effective in preventing seizures, particularly in the context of eclampsia, due to its action on the cerebral cortex. However, it does not lower blood pressure. Instead, its primary role is as an anticonvulsant and a tocolytic (uterine relaxant), not as an antihypertensive agent. MgSO4’s role in managing hypertension is minimal, and it is not used specifically for blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent: This statement is true. MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic to relax the uterus in a dose-dependent manner. It helps in managing preterm labor by relaxing uterine contractions.

 

Option B. MgSO4 is continued up to 24 hours after delivery or the last attack of seizure: This statement is true. Magnesium sulfate is continued for 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure to prevent recurrence of seizures and to provide adequate time for stabilization.

 

Option D. In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but the maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function: This statement is true. In patients with renal failure, the loading dose of MgSO4 can be given, but the maintenance dose should be carefully adjusted due to impaired excretion of magnesium, which could lead to toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is used for preventing seizures in eclampsia and causes uterine relaxation but does not lower blood pressure.

 

Ref: Page no 1867, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Malformations
Polyhydramnios
Fetal Macrosomia

questions.text: All the followings are seen in Gestational Diabetes Mellitus except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malformations

 

Congenital malformations are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are more associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus. When diabetes is present and uncontrolled in the first trimester, particularly with an HbA1C greater than 10%, there is a higher risk of congenital malformations. The most commonly affected system is cardiac, with Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) being the most common anomaly. A very rare but characteristic anomaly associated with severe diabetes is Mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, characterized by an Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) greater than 25 or a Single Deepest Pocket (SDP) greater than 8, is common in pregnancies complicated by GDM. It results from increased fetal urination due to hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. Fetal Macrosomia: Fetal macrosomia, defined as a birth weight greater than 4 kg, is a common complication of GDM. It is associated with excessive fat deposition, particularly around the shoulders, increasing the risk of shoulder dystocia during delivery.

 

Option D. Neonatal Hypoglycemia: Neonatal hypoglycemia, with blood glucose levels less than 45 mg/dl, is common in infants of mothers with GDM, especially if maternal blood sugar levels were unstable during labor. This occurs because the fetus produces excess insulin in response to maternal hyperglycemia, leading to low blood sugar levels after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital anomalies are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2787

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start plotting the graph? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4cm

 

  • In the WHO modified partograph, labor ((Cervical dilatation vs time)  is plotted on a graph and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In the WHO modified partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm so when answering a question read carefully what is asked – WHO modified partograph or WHO Labor care guide

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plotting on the partograph should start at 4 cm cervical dilatation during the active phase of labor.

 

Ref: Page no 152, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 7th edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

 

Explanation:

 

 Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:

 

  • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta.
  • The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not an appropriate management for a uterine septum in a woman desiring fertility. This would completely eliminate her ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty: While laparoscopy can be used to visualize the external uterine anatomy, metroplasty (surgical correction of the uterus) is better performed via hysteroscopy for a uterine septum. Laparoscopy is more invasive and not the first-line approach for this condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty: Laparotomy is an open surgical procedure that involves a larger incision in the abdomen. This approach is unnecessarily invasive for the correction of a uterine septum, which can be effectively managed with a less invasive hysteroscopic approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a uterine septum, especially in a woman seeking fertility, is hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty), which involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum and improve reproductive outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis in view of the following points
    • Age
    • Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea
    • Adnexal mass with ascites

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy may present with weight loss, ascites and a pelvic mass. But a young age and amenorrhea do not go in favor of ovarian malignancy

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy will be an acute presentation and will not present with fever/ weight loss

 

Option D. Submucous fibroid: Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia/ inter-menstrual bleeding and the uterus will be uniformly enlarged. There will not be any pelvic mass. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis with a tubo-ovarian mass is suspected in young patients presenting with low-grade fever, weight loss, amenorrhea, and a pelvic mass with signs of ascites.

 

Ref: Page no 141, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Previous ectopic pregnancy
Previous history of abortion

questions.text: Which of the following would be considered as an absolute contraindication for insertion of copper T to a patient? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Unmotivated patient

 

Inserting a copper T intrauterine device (IUD) requires the patient to be motivated and consent to the procedure. An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent should never undergo the procedure. This is because the successful use of an IUD requires patient understanding, willingness to comply with follow-up care, and adherence to guidelines for managing any potential side effects or complications.

 

Absolute contraindications for the use of copper IUDs include:

 

  • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
  • Post-abortal sepsis, puerperal sepsis, current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), or genital tuberculosis
  • Cancers such as endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, and gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
  • Large fibroids distorting the uterine cavity or Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Menorrhagia: While menorrhagia is a relative contraindication, as the copper IUD can exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding, it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Previous ectopic pregnancy: A history of ectopic pregnancy is a consideration but not an absolute contraindication for copper IUD use.

 

Option D. Previous history of abortion: A previous history of abortion is not an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper IUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper T intrauterine device (IUD).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 480

questions.text: Post-partum IUCD insertion can be inserted till? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48h

 

Postpartum IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is classified into early postpartum and late postpartum insertion.

 

  • Early Postpartum IUCD (PPIUCD): This can be further divided into:
     
    • Within 10 minutes of placental delivery: This is known as immediate PPIUCD insertion.
    • After 10 minutes but within 48 hours of delivery: This is still considered early postpartum insertion and can be performed either after vaginal delivery or during a cesarean section.
       

If the IUCD is not inserted within this 48-hour window, it cannot be inserted until after six weeks postpartum. This period between 48 hours and six weeks is a contraindicated window for IUCD insertion due to the increased risk of expulsion and complications.

 

  • Late Postpartum IUCD: This insertion is done after six weeks postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum. The period between 48 hours and six weeks is contraindicated for IUCD insertion.

questions.text: Identify the grip shown in the image below: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral grip

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold manoeuvres)

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip /Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

The Lateral grip, also known as the Umbilical grip or Second Leopold's maneuver, is used to assess the position of the fetus in the uterus by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen. This grip helps determine the location of the fetal back and limbs.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Pawlik's grip: Also known as the First pelvic grip or Third Leopold's maneuver, Pawlik's grip involves palpating the lower uterine segment to determine the fetal presenting part (e.g., whether it is a head or breech presentation).

 

Option C. Pelvic grip: This term is sometimes used to refer to the Second pelvic grip or Fourth Leopold's maneuver, which is used to assess the fetal engagement and the degree of descent in the pelvic cavity.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the First Leopold's maneuver, which involves palpating the upper part of the uterus (fundus) to identify the fetal presentation (e.g., head or breech) and the lie of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lateral grip (Second Leopold's maneuver) is used to assess the position of the fetal back and limbs by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.
